moves.1... e5: As Black, I've been thinking of trying the Pirc Defence, but this move works good as well.
moves.2. Nf3: This move was played around 100 years ago and is considered the best response for White.
moves.2... Nc6: Black doesn't have too much responses to White's second move, but White has a lot of responses to Black's second move.
moves.4. Nc3: Now, this looks like it transposed into the Four Knights Game Italian Variation.
moves.4... Bc5 5. d3 d6: So far, both sides aquired symmetry. Nothing new here...
moves.6. h3: I talked to a chess coach about this move and it seems like castling is necessary before playing this move. Therefore, this move was not necessary.
moves.6... Nd4: Okay. I hope White takes my Knight because it seems like his best move at the point.
moves.7. Ng5: Trapped Knight. Now you know why I liked Nxd4 better.
moves.7... Be6: At the same time, I had to protect f7 at costs that include castling, which I don't mind giving up.
moves.8. Be3 Qe7: This move is okay, but lets face it, I thought castling was better.
moves.9... Bxd5 10. exd5: It is official: the LSB is a bad Bishop.
moves.10... O-O-O: A risky move, although I don't think that the Kingside is any safer at this point.
moves.11... e4 12. dxe4: It's my opponent's mistake of not taking the Knight. I don't know why he did this move, but I perhaps had no reason to play 11...e4
moves.12... Nxe4: This is no good either. 13.cxd4 Nxg5 14.Bxg5 Qxg5 dxc5 15.dxc5 Bxc5 is what I originally thought would happen, but White made it easier to avoid the unnecessary material loss.
moves.15. Kf1: And this moves enforces the win even more.
moves.15... Nxe3+ 16. Ke1 Nxd1+: I will now be twelve points up.
moves.17. Kxd1 Qe3: I get irritated at myself for not taking a free Bishop. As they say, "Better safe than sorry."
moves.18. Kc2 Qf2+ 19. Kb3: Now the King is out in the open wanting to kill himself. The problem now is getting to him.
moves.19... Qxg2: I didn't really find anything that would help me win permanently. For my own benefit, I decide to wreck my opponent's pawn structures.
moves.20. f4: Qxb2 shall win the game, but I can't go full throttle and lose the Queen for nothing.
moves.20... a6: Plan B: I try to imagine what my opponent's game look like if I won the bishop for nothing. It seems like maybe I should chase it away from the d5 pawn.
moves.21. Bd3: Unfortunately, I could not take the bishop. In fact, this was my consequence for not taking the bishop earlier.
moves.23. Bxf7: I was not expecting that, but I didn't care.
moves.23... Qb5+: Plan C: Queenside pawn push when or if I distract the Rooks... not a very bright plan.
moves.26... Rfe8: I set up my Rook and I will see if g6 is possible.
moves.27. a4: Free pawn. Honestly, I don't know what was up with me on my next move.
moves.30. f6 Rhf8 31. f7 Re7: I thought that Plan B was the "impossible plan by now and that C was too risky and it gets me into traps. This move was not necessary. 31...Rxe6! is what I missed. 32.Rxe6 Qd5+ would prove that plan B was still alive.
moves.32. Ka2: I still could do Rxe6 and get the same results.
moves.32... g5: This move was worse than Re7.
moves.33. b4 Bf2: Ther was still another idea. Rfxf7 or Rexf7. I don't know which one is better, but I have a great feeling that they're both equal.
moves.34... Qxf7+ 35. Ka3: and ther goes the Rook that Plan C covered. Atleast one of my plans worked, but remember that I wasted moves and lost many opportunities.
moves.35... Rxe1 36. Rxe1: With the Rooks gone, I can now forget about the Bishop unless otherwise.
moves.36... Bxe1: My plan: simply take the c3 pawn with the Bishop and invade White's corrupted forces.
moves.37... Bxc3 38. Bd1 Qf1: There was a better move than this 38...Qc4, then Rf2 creates a crushing combination that the Bishop cannot withstand by itself. 38...Qc4 39.Bb3 Qxb4+ 40.Ka2 Rf2+ 41.Kb1 Qxb3+ 42.Kc1 Qc2#.
moves.39... Qa1+ 40. Kb3 Qb2+: You might laugh at me here (I don't blame you), but I actually thought this was checkmate and did not pay attention to the c4 square.
moves.41. Kc4: Until he moved there. However, I did not lose my grip on White.
moves.41... Bxb4: This move wins permanently. No matter what move he plays, I'll respond with Re1.
moves.43... Qc3#: That's the game. Something occured to me during this game; it was the motto, "When faced with a challenge, look for a way, not a way out." Aside from missing out on early opportunities and missing out on tactical advantages, I finally pulled though and checkmated White. There is more than one way to do something. Next time, I should think more slowly to get the best moves possible. You make a decision, it becomes your choice and it leads you to your consequences.
